bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kayâs pêyak okimâw , nîsoh okimâwak , oskinîkiwak , pêyak owîkimâkanah miyosiyiwa ; wiya mîna miyosiw aw ôskinîkiw , okimâw . Of old there was a chief, there were two chiefs, and one had a beautiful wife, and he, too, a young man, was handsome, that chief.

êkwah owîkimâkanah têhtapiwak ê-sipwêhtêcik , ayâhciyiniwah êh-ntonawâcik , ê-wîh-kakwê-kimotamawât otêmiyiwa , ahpôh ta-nipahât wâpamât ; He and his wife rode away from camp to look for Blackfoot, as he meant to steal their horses, or to kill them, if he saw them;
êkos ê-ihtêyihtahk kâ-sipwêhtêt . such was his intention as they set out.
êh-tipiskâyik , kâ-sipwêhtêcik owîkimâkanah , êh-nîsicik pikôh . At night they set out, he and his wife alone.
piyisk wâpaniyiw , ê-pa-pmi-têhtapicik . Dawn came and they were still riding along.
êwakô kapê-kîsik pimohtêwak ; piyisk tipiskâw . They went on that whole day, until night fell.
kapêsiwak , êh-nipâcik . They camped and slept.
êh-wâpahk sipwêhtêwak . In the morning they went on.
kêkâc êh-âpihta-kîsikâk , wâpamêw mostoswah . Toward noon he saw some buffalos.
nawaswâtêw ; pêyak nipahêw . He pursued them and killed one.
êkotah ayâwak , êh-wiyinihâcik , ê-wîh-mîcisocik . They stayed in that place, preparing the carcass for their meal.
piyis kinwês êkotah ayâwak . They stayed there quite a while.
êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , osîhtâw aw îskwêw ê-wîh-nîmâcik kâhkêwakwah . After they had eaten, the woman made dried meat to carry along.
piyis tipiskâyiw êkot êh-ayâcik . Night came upon them there.
êh-wâpaniyik sipwêhtêwak . In the morning they went on.
êwakô mîna kapê-kîsik pimohtêwak . All that day, too, they kept going.
piyisk êh-tipiskâyik , wâpani-pimohtêwak . When night came, they kept on till dawn.
piyis ê-spi-kîsikâyik , êkoyikohk cîk êkwah ayâwak itah êy-ihtatêyimâcik iyahciyiniwah . When it was full daylight, they had got close to where they thought the Blackfoot to be.
ômis îsiyihkâsoyiwah kâ-ntonawât : kinêpikoyiniwak isiyîhkâsoyiwa . This was the name of the people they were seeking out: Snakes, was their name.
tahkih âkawâyihk pimohtêwak , ê-kostahkik ta-wâpamikocik . They advanced always behind knolls, afraid that the enemy might see them.

sîpiy itah ê-pimihtiniyik , êkotah tahkih pimohtêw êh-kâsot , âskaw ê-sâkêwêt , ê-wîh-kakwêh-wâpahtahk kêkway . Where a river flowed by, there he went along; concealing himself, but coming forth every now and then, to see what could be seen.
tahki êkosi tôtam ; piyis mîna tipiskâyiw . He kept doing this, until night came.
êkotah kapêsiw itahk ê-sakâyik . He camped there in the thicket.
êkotah êh-nipât piyis wâpan . He slept there until dawn.
êh-waniskâcik , êkwah ma-mîcisôwak . When they got up, they ate.
êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , nanâpâcihôw , êh-kâsîhkwêt , êh-tômihkwêt , êh-sîkahot . When they had eaten, he made himself ready, washing and painting his face, and combing his hair.
êkoyikohk ispimihk ayâyiwah pîsimwah . By this time the sun stood high.
pasikôw , ê-sipwêhtêt , owîkimâkanah êh-nakâtât êkotah , ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamât kâ-pê-ntonawât . He arose and, leaving his wife there, went away to try to see those whom he was seeking out.

êh-mis-ôsêtinâyik , êkotah êh-âmaciwêt , êh-nanâtawâpit , piyisk kîsih-âmaciwêw ; pôtih kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpah ê-mihcêniyikih . He climbed a large knoll to look out. When he reached the top, there he beheld a great many tents.
mihcêt wâpamêw misatimwah mîkiwâhpihk . He saw many horses by the camp.
êkosi wâpahtam pîhtêyis pêyak mîkiwâhp êh-misâyik . He saw a large tent in the center of the others.
cîk êkotah apisîs sakâyiw . Close by was a small thicket.
êwakonih kinêpikoyiniwah ; êwakonih kâ-pê-nitonawât . Those were the Snakes; those were the ones he sought.
êkotah ay-ayâw . He stayed there.
piyisk kêkâc âpihtâ-kîsikâyiw , êh-ka-kitâpamât . Until nearly noon he watched them.
piyis nîhtaciwêw , owîkimâkanah êh-itohtêt . At last he came down from the hill and went to where his wife was.

ômisih itêw :
niwîkimâkan , ôtah awasâyihk misâw ôtênaw . This is what he said to her: “My wife, here behind the hill is a large town.

seg.gloss: You too shall see the people.
Get yourself ready; wash your face; paint your face; comb your hair.

p.seg: tâns êtokê ka-pmâtisiyahk , wâpamikoyahki , itêw . Who knows if we shall live when we are seen,” he said to her.

awa iskwêw ê-kîsi-nanâpâcihot ,
pitah mîcisotân , itwêw awa nâpêw . When she had made herself ready, “First let us eat,” said the man.
tâpwê mîcisôwak . So they ate.

êh-kîsi-mîcisocik ,
âmaciwêtân , kîstah ta-wâpahtaman ê-mihcêticik kâ-pêh-ntonawâyahkok . When they had eaten, “Let us mount the hill, so that you too may see how many they are whom we have come to seek.

seg.q: mâskôc pimâtisiyahkoh , t-âcimoyan , kôhtâwiy t-âcimostawat êsi-wâpahtamanê .
seg.gloss: Perhaps, if we live, you will tell the tale, you will tell your father the tale, of what you have seen.”

p.seg: tâpwê pasikôwak , êh-âmaciwêcik . So they arose and climbed the hill.
itah kâ-kiy-osâpahtahk mîkiwâhpah , êkotah êh-takohtêcik , nama kêkway wâpahtam . When they came to the place from which he had seen the camp, he saw nothing at all.
kahkiyaw sipwêhtêyiwa , êh-piciyit . They had all moved camp and gone away.
misiwê êh-ât-ayîtâpit , namoya wâpamêw . Though he looked in every direction, he did not see them.
êkwah kiskinôhamawêw owîkimâkanah . Then he pointed it out to his wife.
êokôh kâ-sakâk animah , êkotah kâ-kîh-ayâkih mîkiwâhpah , itêw owîkimâkanah . “Over by that thicket is where the tents stood,” he told her.

êkwah nîhtaciwêwak , otêmiwâwa êh-otinâcik , êkwah ê-têhtapicik , êh-itohtêcik ita kâ-kîh-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpah . Then they descended the hill, took their horses, mounted, and went to where he had seen the camp.
tâpwêy otihtamwak itah ê-kîh-wîkiyit ôhih matokahpah . They came to the abandoned camp.
piyisk otihtamwak ômâ kâ-sakâsiyik , êkotah kâ-kîh-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp êh-misâyik . at last they came to that thicket, where he had seen the large tent.
êkoyikohk tahkih ê-nanâtawâpit , kâ-wâpahtahk êh-îkwaskwaniyik . As he thus kept looking about, he saw that the sky had clouded.

piyisk ômis îtêw :
mâskôt ta-kimiwan , itêw owîkimâkanah . At last he spoke: “Perhaps it is going to rain,” he said to his wife.
sêskisiwak ma kâ-sakâsiyik . They went into the thicket.

seg.gloss: “Let us set up our tent.

p.seg: ka-sâpopânânaw , kimiwahki , itêw owîkimâkanah . We shall be drenched if it rains,” he said to his wife.
tâpwê osîhtâwak nîpiyah ohci . So they built it, of leaves.

omis îtwêw awa yskwêw :
niwîkimâkan , ôtah matokapihk kêkway nikih-wâpahtên . Thus spoke the woman: “My husband, there in the camp site I saw something.
mahtih nka-ntawâpahtên , itêw onâpêmah . Let me go look at it,” she said to her husband.

êhag , itwêw awa nâpêw ,
â , niwîkimâkan , nanâtawâpi , itêw owîkimâkanah , “Very well,” said he; “Yes, Wife, go look,” he said to her;

seg.gloss: “If you see anything, come back here.”

p.seg: êkosi sipwêhtêw aw îskwêw . êy-ôtihtahk ôma matokahp , kâ-wâpahtahk , êkotah êh-astêyik , êh-wêwêkinikâtêyik papakiwêyânêkinohk . Accordingly the woman went and approached the empty camp, where she had seen something lying wrapped in cloth.
otinam , êh-âpihkonahk . She took it and unwrapped it.

êh-wâ-wâpahtahk , wiyamanah nanâtohk êsinâkosiyit , êkwah ocihcîhk êh-ay-ayêsisimât ,
tanimâ êh-miyosit ! êh-itêyihtahk . When she examined it, it looked like paints of all colors, and she turned it over and over in her hand, thinking, “How beautiful!”

mêkwâc êkosi êh-tôtahk , mêkwâc ,
kêkway miyâmay , êh-itêyihtahk , êh-itâpit , âsay êkotah kâ-takohtêyit êh-têhtapiyit oskinîkiwah . While she was doing this and thinking, “Surely this amounts to something,” when she looked up, there had approached, meanwhile, a youth on horseback.
mistahê miyosiyiwah ôh ôskinîkiwah , acosisah ê-nîmâskwêyit êkwah câpihcikanis êkwah cîkahikani-pakamâkanis . Very handsome was this youth, and he was armed with arrows, a lance, and a tomahawk.

êkwah oskotâkayiw mîkisah kikamoyiwa , êkwah sihkosiwayânah oskotâkayihk , otâsiyihk mînah ; mînah otakohp mîkisiwiyiw . And beads were on his coat and weasel-skins on his coat and his breeches; and beaded was his robe.
êh-kitotikot , namoya nisitohtawêw ; êh-kitôtât , wîstah namoya nisitohtâk . When he spoke to her, she did not understand his speech, and when she spoke to him, he, too, did not understand her.
kêkwayah kiyah ? itinamâk . “What manner of person are you?” he asked her by signs.
âh , niyah pîtos-iskwêw , itinamawêw . “Oh, a woman of another tribe,” she told him by signs.
âh , têhtap ôtah , itik aw îskwêw ; “Now, mount here,” he told her;
kisiwâk ôtah êh-kapêsihk , itinamâk ; “Close by here is the camp,” he made sign to her;

seg.gloss: my father is the chief.

p.seg: êwôkô oma êtah ê-kîh-wîkit nôhtâwiy , itinamâk . This very place is where my father had his camp,” he told her by signs.
cêskwah , itinamawêw awa yskwêw ; “Presently,” she told him by gesture;

seg.q: ô , ôma kâ-sakâk , êkotah niwîkimâkan ayâw .
seg.gloss: “Over in that thicket is my husband.
Him I give to you; kill him.
When you have killed him, I will go with you.

seg.q: nîsoh misatimwak êkotah ayâwak ê-mihkawikîcik , êkwah awa niwîkimâkan k-ôhtohtêyâhk êh-okimâwit .
seg.gloss: Two swift horses are there, and my husband, who is a chief whence we came.

p.seg: nipahacih , kîsta kik-ôkimâwin , itêw . If you slay him, you yourself by that will be a chief,” she told him.
âhag , itwêw ôw oskinîkiw . “Very well,” said the youth.
ômisi nik-êtâw , itwêw aw îskwêw . “Thus I shall speak to him,” said the woman. LB: What she would say was not dictated.
niyâ , itêw . “Go on,” he told her.

ati-sipwêhtêw , ê-sêskisit , owîkimâkanah êh-itât ,
niwîkimâkan , wiyamanak ês ôkih mistah êh-miyosicik , itêw . She went from there to the grove and said to her husband, “My husband, it seems that these are beautiful paints,” she told him.
mahtih , itwêw awah nâpêw , êh-nahapit aw îskwêw , êh-wâ-wâpamâyit owîkimâkanah . “Let us see,” said he; and the woman sat down while her husband examined it.

ômisi itêyihtam awa nâpêw :
nikah-wâpamâwak ôkih , itêyihtam ; Thus thought the man: “I shall look at these things,” he thought;

mâskôc awa awiyah wâpamêw , itêyimêw owîkimâkanah , tahkih êh-nanâtawâpiyit ; kêtâpamâcih tapahciskwêyiwah . “Perhaps she has seen someone,” he thought of his wife, for she kept looking out as though she sought some sight and, whenever he watched her, would lower her head.
kîtahtawê kâh-pêhtahk êh-pê-pimohtêyit ayîsiyiniwah . Suddenly he heard a man approaching.
ê-wîh-pasikôt , owîkimâkanah k-otihtinikot , ê-wîh-otamihikot . When he tried to get on his feet, his wife laid her hands on him and tried to distract his attention.
êh-kwêskipayihot , âsay ka-wîh-cîkahokot oskinîkiwah . When he jumped aside, the youth was about to strike him with his tomahawk. CHECK ka -> kâ
wîwah ôhi âh-âkowêpinêw . He threw his wife before him as a shield, and kept doing so.
namoya kîh-cîkahok ôh ôskinîkiwah . The youth could not strike him.
piyis nayawapiw aw îskwêw . At last the woman became tired.
aw ôskinîkiw oskâtihk pahkisiniyiwah ôh îskwêwah ; kawiwêpiskâk . She fell against the young man's legs, knocking him over.
piyisk otinam ocîkahikanisiyiw , êwôkô ohci êh-câ-cîkahwêt . at last he got hold of the other's hatchet, and kept striking him with it.
nipahêw ; ostikwâniyiw manisamwêw . He slew him; he took his scalp.

êkosi êkwah ômis îtêw :
niwîkimâkan , êh-pêyakot ciy awah ? Thereupon he spoke to her: “My wife, was this man alone?”

êhag
itwêw awa yskwêw . “Yes,” answered she.

seg.gloss: “Was this all the equipment he had?”

p.seg:
nama wiya , itwêw aw îskwêw ,
masinasôw-atimwah êh-têhtapit , sihkosiwayânasâkay kîh-kikasâkêw ; mîn êkotôwahk kîh-kikitâsêw . “No,” she said, “for he rode a brindled horse, and a weasel-skin coat he wore, and breeches of the like.

seg.gloss: Beaded was his blanket-robe.
And arrows he bore and a lance.”

p.seg: tânisi mâka êy-itêyihtaman kâ-miciminiyan ? êh-miywêyimat cî ? itêw owîkimâkanah . “And what was your thought, that you held me? Was it that you loved him?” he asked his wife.
êhag , itwêw awâh iskwêw . “Yes,” she answered.

seg.gloss: “And how did you see him?”

seg.q: mêkwâc ôkih wiyamanak êh-wâpamakik , êkotah kâ-takohtêt .
seg.gloss: “While I was looking at these paints, to that place he came.
'Come, mount my horse,' he said to me;
'I will take you home with me,' he said.
'No,' I said to him,

seg.q:
ôma kâ-sakâsik êkotah ayâw niwîkimâkan , nititâw ,
nîso misatimwak ê-mîhkawikîcik , k-ôhtohtêyâhk êh-okimâwit awa niwîkimâkan .
seg.gloss: 'Over in yonder grove is my husband,' I told him; 'Two swift horses and my husband, who is a chief whence we came.
I give him to you to slay;
you will be a chief, it you slay him,' I said to him.

p.seg: êhag , êh-isit , kâ-pê-sêskisiyân , itwêw aw îskwêw . When he said, 'Yes,' to me, I came back to this grove,” said the woman.
kah , itwêw awa nâpêw ; “So that is it!” said the man;
êkosi mâka oyahpis awa kitêhtapiwin , itwêw awa nâpêw ; “Well then, do you saddle this your mount,” said he;
tapasîtân , itêw . “Let us flee from here,” he said to her.
êkosi oyahpitastimwêwak . Accordingly they saddled their horses.
êh-matâwisicik , êkotah nîpawiyiwa aw oskinîkiw kâ-kîh-têhtapit ; When they came to the trail, there stood the horse that youth had ridden;
kahkiyaw otayôwinisah êkotah aspapiwinihk tahkopitêyiwah . all his clothes were tied there to the saddle.
otinêw awa nâpêw , êh-kîwêcik , êh-tapasîcik . The man took the horse, and they turned homeward in flight.
êwakôh kapê-kîsik pimipayiwak , piyis êh-tipiskâyik . [no translation: They rode all that day, until nightfall.]
kapê-tipisk namoya wîh-nipâwak ; [no translation: All night they wouldn't sleep.]
piyis wâpan . [no translation: Finally it was dawn.]
êko mina kapê-kîsik pimipayiwak ; piyis tipiskâw ; kapê-tipisk pimipayiwak . They rode all that day, until nightfall, and all night they rode.
kêkâc êh-wâpaniyik , êkotah kapêsiwak . Toward dawn they made camp.
êh-nipâcik , êh-wâpaniyik , êkwah ê-waniskâcik , âsay ispi-kîsikâyiw . They slept and the next morning, when they arose, it was already broad daylight.

êkwa êh-kîwêcik , êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , âsay kisiwâk kâh-wîkicik ayowêpiwak , ômah ôstikwâniyiw ê-wîh-osihtât . Then they made for home, and at noon, close to the camp of their band, they halted, for he meant to prepare the scalp he had taken.
âh , tipiskâki ka-takôhtânânaw , niwîkimâkan , itêw . “At nightfall we shall arrive, my wife,” he said to her.
êhag , twêw aw îskwêw . “Yes,” she answered.
êkotah wiy aw iskwêw na-nipâw . The woman dozed from time to time.

iyikohk êh-kîsihtât ôma kâ-kîh-manisahk wastakayiwa ôhi kâ-nipahât ,
â , niwîkimâkan , waniskâ ! When he had prepared the scalp he had cut from the one he had slain, “Now, Wife, get up!

seg.gloss: I have finished it;
now let us first eat;

p.seg: kîh-mîcisoyahkoh , kkîwânânaw , itêw . when we have eaten we shall go home,” he said to her.
êkosi ê-kîh-mîcisocik , êkwah sipwêhtêwak . Accordingly, when they had eaten, they set out.
nôhtaw tipiskâw . Night overtook them.
itah kâ-wîkicik , êh-nâh-nipâwiht takohtêwak . They arrived at the camp after their people had gone to sleep.
omanâcimâkanah wîkiyihk êkotah sakahpitêw ôhih kâ-pêsiwât misatimwah . At his father-in-law's lodge he tied up the horse he brought.
kahkiyaw otayôwinisiyiwa êkotah tahkopitam ôhi kâ-nipahât oskinîkiwah . To the lodge he tied all the clothes of the young man he had slain.
ostikwâniyiw tâpiskahêw ôhi misatimwah . He hung the scalp round the horse's neck.
êkwah wîstâwah wîkiyihk cimatâw skwâhtêmihk câpihcikanis ; At his brother-in-law's lodge he set into the ground the lance;
pahkih êkotah tahkopitam om ôstikwân . part of the scalp he tied to it.
êkos îsi kîwêwak , ê-kawisimocik . Then they went to their tent and went to bed.

êkwah kîksêpâ awa kisêyiniw êh-wayawît , kâ-wâpamât ôhi misatimwah êh-pêsiwâyit onahâhkisîma . Then in the morning, when that old man went out of the lodge, he saw the horse which his son-in-law had brought.
êkos îsi pîhtokêw . He went back into the tent.
nôtokêsiw , waniskâh ! êsa kitânisinaw kâh-takohtêcik , êkosi itêw . “Wife, get up! Our daughter and her husband have arrived,” he told her.
êkosi waniskâw awa nôtokêsiw , êh-paminawasot . So the old woman got up and cooked.
êkosi wiy âwa kisêyiniw wayawîw ; The old man went out;
otinam ôh ayôwinisan , êh-postayôwinisêt . he took those clothes and put them on.
êh-kîsi-postayôwinisêt , têhtapiw ôhih kâ-miyosiyit kâ-pêsiwâyit onahâhkisîmah , êh-at-sipwêhtêt . When he had dressed, he mounted the handsome horse his son-in-law had brought, and set out.

omis îtwêw :
waniskâk ! waniskâk ! yiniwitik ! This he cried forth: “Arise! Arise, men!
wâpamik êsihoyân , itwêw , êh-wâsakâmêt ômah ôtênaw . Behold me, how I am dressed,” he cried, going round the village.

tâpwê tahtoh êh-pêkomât , êh-waniskâyit , êh-kitâpamikot , mistahê miywâsiniyiwa ayôwinisah êh-wâpahtamoht . And truly, as he awoke them with his calls, and they arose and looked at him, very handsome were the garments they beheld on him.
êsah onahâhkisîma têkosiniyit , êkosi itêyihtamwak ayîsiyiniwak . “It is plain that his son-in-law has arrived,” thought the people.
êkosi kahkiyaw waniskâwak ayîsiyiniwak , êh-miywêyihtahkik êh-takosiniyit otôkimâmiwâwa . So all the people arose, rejoicing that their chief had arrived.
êkoyikohk takohtêw wîkiwâhk ô kisêyiniw . In due time the old man came to his house.

omis îtêw :
nitaw-âsim kitânisinaw , itêw . “Go give food to our daughter,” he told his wife.
tâpwê nitaw-âsamêw ôw nôtokêsiw . So the old woman went to give them food.

êh-kîh-mîcisocik , omis îtwêw ôw okimâw :
wîhtamaw kôhtâwiy ta-ntomêw okimâwah , êkosi îtêw ô ôkimâw . When they had eaten, thus spoke that chief: “Tell your father to call the chiefs,” he said.
tâpwê wîhtamawêw ôhtâwiyah ta-ntomâyit okimâwa . Accordingly she told her father to summon the chieftains.
tâpwê ntomêw kahkiyaw . He summoned them all.
okimâwiw ninahâhkisîm ; kintomikowâw , êkos îtêw . “A chief is my son-in-law; he calls you,” he said to them.
tâpwê pâh-pîhtokêwak okimâwak . One after another the chieftains entered.

seg.gloss: “Now, that you may smoke I have called you.

p.seg: tans êtokê êh-îsi-wâpahtahk ? kitêyiminâwâw êtokê , itêw . 'How has he fared?' no doubt you are asking yourselves about me in your thought,” he said to them.
êhag , itwêwak . “Yes,” they answered.

êkwah âcimôw om ôtê k-êtohtêt k-êsi-wâpahtahk kêkwaya , owîkimâkanah k-êtikot , kâh-miciminikot ê-wîh-nipahiht . Then he told them how he had fared in the place to which he had gone, what his wife had said to him, and how she had held him when he was to be slain.
kahkiyaw êwakô âcimôw . He told all.
kisiwâsiw awa kisêyiniw , otânisah êh-tôtamiyit . The old man was angry at what his daughter had done.

wayawîw awa kisêyiniw êh-têpwêt ,
ahahaw , oskinîkitik , iskwêtik , miyawâtamok ; The old man went out of the lodge and called, “Hear, youths, women; rejoice;
nîmihitok , âyimâc êh-pimâtisit ninahâkisîm , êkos îtwêw . dance, for my son-in-law has lived through great danger,” he called.
tâpwê mawacihitôwak , ê-mihawâtahkik , êh-nîmihitocik . Accordingly they gathered and rejoiced and danced.

êkwah aw ôkimâw ,
pê-kanawâpahkêk , itâwak . Then that chief, “Come and look on,” they were told.
mitoni wawêsiwak owîkimâkanah , êh-kitâpamâcik , ê-nîmihitowit . Highly arrayed were he and his wife, as they watched the others dance.
kitahtawê aw ôkimâw ohtawakayiw owîkimânah kâh-miciminamowât . Suddenly that chief seized his wife by one ear.
ma-mawimôw aw îskwêw . She began to cry.
kiyâm api ! itwêw aw ôkimâw , êh-manisamwât ohtawakayiw , kwêski mînah . “Hold still!” said the chief, and cut off her one ear and then the other.
êkosi êkwah kîpipayiyiwa , ê-nêstôhkwêkawiyit , êh-nipiyit . Then she sank to the earth, bleeding to death.
âhci pikoh miyawâtam ô kisêyiniw , otânisah êh-nipahimiht . Nevertheless the old man continued to rejoice, when his daughter had been killed.
êkosi kîwêw aw ôkimâw ; ay-apiw wîkihk . Then that chief went home; he sat in his lodge.

êkwah êh-pôyocik kâh-nîmihitocik , êh-kîwêt awa kisêyiniw , wîkiwâhk êh-pîhtokêt , otânisah pêyak kêyâpic omis îtêw : When they ceased dancing, the old man went home, entered the tent, and to his other daughter spoke as follows:

seg.gloss: “Come, dear daughter, arise; go to my son-in-law.

p.seg: kimis itah kâ-kîh-apit , êkotah nahapih , itêw . There where your elder sister used to sit, there take your seat,” he said to her.
êkosi itohtêw aw oskinîkiskwêw . Accordingly that young woman went there.
tâpwê nahapistawêw ôh ôkimâwa . She seated herself by that chief.
mwêstas itohtêw awa kisêyiniw . Later the old man went there.
êh-pîhtokêt , pôtih otânisah kîh-apiyiwah . When he entered, there sat his daughter.

seg.gloss: “Now, my daughter, deal lovingly with my son-in-law.

seg.q: êkwah kiya mîna , kîspin namoya kikitimâkêyimâw ninahâhkisîm , kîst êkosi ka-wâpahtên , anohc kâ-kîsikâk k-êsi-wâpahtahk kimis , êkâh êh-kitimâkêyimât onâpêmah .
seg.gloss: For you too, if you do not take loving care of my son-in-law, you too shall fare even so as your elder sister has fared on this day, because she did not deal lovingly with her husband.
You saw how your elder sister was slain.

p.seg: kitimâkêyimaci ninahâhkisîm , kîstah ka-kitimâkêyimik , itêw awa kisêyiniw otânisah . If you deal lovingly with my son-in-law, he will give loving care to you,” the old man told his daughter.
êkosi . That is all.
